awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: Collaborative Research: Developing and Deploying SKOPE--A resource for Synthesizing Knowledge of Past Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop SKOPE (Synthesizing Knowledge of Past Environments), a freely available Web site that will provide easy access to state-of-the-art measurements and reconstructions of long-term environmental data, such as rainfall, temperature, plant and animal distributions, streamflow, and soils. Given a time period and a location, it will display the data graphically and will permit users to download the original high-resolution environmental data. By enabling scholars to easily discover, explore, visualize, and synthesize knowledge of environmental stability and change over centuries or millennia, SKOPE will empower reproducible research on the effects of climatic variation on human societies and the substantial impacts of humans on ancient and modern environments. It will also facilitate ongoing improvement of paleoenvironmental reconstructions. SKOPE will transform vast amounts of prior data collection, modeling, and research into usable environmental knowledge, enhancing the infrastructure of scientific research in such diverse disciplines as agronomy, anthropology, archaeology, ecology, economics, geography, political science, sociology, and sustainability. SKOPE will also make available publicly funded paleoenvironmental data and models to users in industry and government. For example, planners will be able to use SKOPE?s long-term environmental reconstructions to investigate vulnerabilities in infrastructure not revealed by historical experience (for example, streamflow or rainfall regimes outside the ranges of those documented historically). Students will have free access to high-quality environmental scenarios in which to situate their studies. Members of the general public will be able to see how ancient environments differed from those of today. Expanding the community able to obtain and use paleoenvironmental information will increase public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology.

Recent research has demonstrated that investigations of contemporary societal problems can benefit from the use of long-term environmental data and from comparisons with cases in which the interactions of human societies with their environments is well-documented over centuries. By providing easy access to time- and place-specific long-term environmental data, this project seeks to facilitate those efforts. SKOPE addresses two critical challenges to contemporary science: increasing access to publicly funded research; and ensuring that scientific results are transparent and reproducible. SKOPE will enable users to easily discover, download, visualize, and explore many sources of paleoenvironmental data that resulted from publicly funded research that are now difficult (at best) to find and use. SKOPE will also provide robust support for reproducible scientific research. Datasets provided by SKOPE will be accompanied by a systematic, comprehensible record of their origin and computational derivation, giving researchers an unprecedented ability to understand how the data were obtained.

por.por_cntn:
The SKOPE project is the latest in an ongoing series of funded efforts to develop SKOPE (Synthesizing Knowledge of Past Environments, https://www.openskope.org/), a resource for scholars who use paleoenvironmental data and models in their research.  Understanding the long-term interactions of human and natural systems is a major focus of research in the social and natural sciences. Even where such interactions are not the focus, contemporary research must accommodate the fact that biotic environments are not stable and that we cannot simply assume that today's environments were replicated in the past. Consequently, scholars who are not experts in reconstructing past environmental conditions require environmental knowledge specific to their spatiotemporal research contexts.  By enabling such scholars to easily discover, explore, visualize, and synthesize knowledge of environments in the recent or remote past, SKOPE aims to enhance research and education in such diverse disciplines as anthropology, archaeology, ecology, economics, geography, political science, sociology, and sustainability.

Many sophisticated reconstructions of past climate have been created and some of these are available online. However, most are impossible to access and use without highly specialized knowledge lacked by most potential users. Our previous project (SKOPE I) aimed to understand scholars' needs for paleoenvironmental data and the technical challenges they face in finding, accessing, and making effective and meaningful use of such data in their research. SKOPE II builds on this understanding to (1) deliver a web-based application that addresses the most critical requirements of scholars who need to find and employ paleoenvironmental data, and to (2) begin to address the fundamental technical challenge of making extremely diverse data sets available through a unified user interface and web application.

Fully understanding the technical requirements for the SKOPE web application entailed evaluating a number of distinct web application architectures and developing multiple, working prototypes of the overall application over the course of the SKOPE II project. The final implementation of the web-application employs industry best practices and is based on NuxtJS, a modern, well-documented and maintainable open source framework for building JavaScript rich web-applications. Careful attention was placed on usability, high-quality geospatial visualizations, and streamlined analysis workflows for viewing a dataset, visualizing data across different spatio-temporal contexts, and performing basic statistical queries on time series data. The web application employs a single Python FastAPI-based backend service that handles requests for metadata, time series data, and summary statistics with a documented OpenAPI compatible interface (https://api.openskope.org/docs). The SKOPE application integrates with the industry-standard GeoServer service to provide geospatial visualizations of data. Public access to the final version of the SKOPE web application is provided at https://app.openskope.org/. 

While standard, state-of-the-art technologies, application architectures, and software engineering methodologies were sufficient to deliver the SKOPE software application, addressing the problem of preparing diverse datasets for inclusion in the SKOPE environment in a transparent and trustworthy manner proved more challenging. Standard GIS (Geographic Information System) approaches and tools yielded workflows for profiling, transforming and otherwise preparing datasets that were difficult to reproduce and reuse, prone to errors, and generally opaque to examination by others. Modern web site search technologies lacked capabilities to index datasets in terms of the detailed provenance information by which scholars select datasets relevant to their specific research questions.  Finally, diversity in how source datasets and associated metadata are represented led to difficulties including subtle processing problems requiring much effort to troubleshoot. Finding ways of making data processing workflows repeatable and reusable was found to be a bottleneck limiting the rate at which we could incorporate new and updated datasets in the SKOPE application.

In partnership with the Whole Tale project (https://wholetale.org/) the SKOPE II team developed new means to represent and share the processing of paleoenvironmental datasets in transparent and reproducible ways.  One innovative method employs a combination of Git repositories, Docker containers, and standardized Makefiles to yield  Reproducible Every Place Research Objects, or REPROs (see https://github.com/repros-dev/repro for an overview of this approach). REPROs can be developed and run on any researcher's own computer and shared with others who wish to reproduce results or reuse and extend the data-processing workflows represented by a REPRO. This effort ultimately led to a new project that will make the preparation workflows for datasets served to users through the SKOPE application transparent and reproducible, both as standalone REPROs that can be run by users anywhere, and as Tales within the Whole Tale platform. It also will enable these data processing workflows to be reused and adapted to prepare new, different kinds of datasets for sharing via the SKOPE application in a transparent and reproducible way.  Going forward, these approaches will provide the means both to incorporate a much larger number and variety of paleoenvironmental datasets within the SKOPE application, and empower SKOPE users to carry out more sophisticated analyses outside of the SKOPE application using datasets and analysis methods customized for their own needs.
